Metallica Interview Canceled after Pirate Bay Row

September 14th, 2008 · No Comments

What do you do in this day and age as an artist when someone “remixes” or edits your artistic output? Metallica has garnered a reputation as an Internet-unfriendly band with their stance on Napster and file sharing in general. In this case, someone has taken their latest album, released on Friday, and edited the songs to make the album “better” (basically, they cut out the slow or repetitive parts and kept the “metal essence”).

Metallica and the creative industries in general need to face reality: your creative output is bits. It’s information and is therefore very easy to manipulate and change these days with audio editing software. That genie cannot be put back into the bottle. So you either embrace it or pick your metaphor: ostrich with its head in the sand? Boy with finger in dike? Dying dinosaur? You can change or society will change without you.

Embracing it means recognizing (a) you are an “alpha” creator. You created this entire work of art from scratch. People will buy your work because you’ve proven before that you make art that people enjoy. However, (b) people who are “beta” creators will take your work of art and attempt to make it better, remix it or change it in a way that they enjoy. This does not detract from your original work and should be seen as a positive: no one wastes their time on irrelevant artists, they want to put their own spin on your good work. I see this as no different from a band who wants to play a cover of some song. They might play the cover in a different tempo or style but this is still a net positive for both the cover band and the original composer/artist.

Metallica Interview Canceled after Pirate Bay Row
